ownPages.title: DefaultFilter
ownPages.content:
Filters messages based on tag and priority.

Messages will be logged if the tag passes both the blacklist and the whitelist, and has a priority greater than or equal to the configured minimum.

Filters messages based on tag and priority.

Messages will be logged if the tag passes both the blacklist and the whitelist, and has a priority greater than or equal to the configured minimum.

addTagToWhitelist

Declare a tag that should be added to the whitelist. Only messages with a tag in the whitelist will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

addTagToBlacklist

Declare a tag that should be added to the blacklist. Only messages with a tag not in the blacklist will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

setMinPriority

Set the minimum priority for log messages. Only messages with a level greater than or equal to priority will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

shouldLog

Given a priority and tag , determine if a message should be logged. It should conform to the whitelist, blacklist, and minimum priority, but additional logic may be present as well.

Returns true if the message should be logged, and false if it should be dropped.

ownPages.title: DelegatingLogger
ownPages.content:
Passes a log message to multiple other loggers

delegates

Passes a log message to multiple other loggers

log

Log a message at a given priority to a platform-specific logging target. The tag is already inferred and the message already formatted at this point.

logException

plus

Returns a copy of this DelegatingLogger with logger appended to its list of delegates .

ownPages.title: DisableInProductionFilter
ownPages.content:
shouldLog

Given a priority and tag , determine if a message should be logged. It should conform to the whitelist, blacklist, and minimum priority, but additional logic may be present as well.

Returns true if the message should be logged, and false if it should be dropped.

ownPages.title: DefaultTagProvider
ownPages.content:
If a tag is not null, use that as the message tag. Otherwise, attempt to infer the tag on supported platforms.

If a tag is not null, use that as the message tag. Otherwise, attempt to infer the tag on supported platforms.

get

Return the tag that should be logged with the current message.

ownPages.title: DefaultMessageFormatter
ownPages.content:
Replaces {} placeholders in the message with positional args.

Replaces {} placeholders in the message with positional args.

format

Formats a log message with positional args and any other contextual information. Tags and logging levels are handled by the ClogLogger and should not be included in this formatted message.

DefaultMessageFormatter

Replaces {} placeholders in the message with positional args.

ownPages.title: PrintlnLogger
ownPages.content:
Logs a message to stdout using println. The priority is displayed with ANSI colors and the tag is prepended to the message if one is provided.

Logs a message to stdout using println. The priority is displayed with ANSI colors and the tag is prepended to the message if one is provided.

log

Log a message at a given priority to a platform-specific logging target. The tag is already inferred and the message already formatted at this point.

PrintlnLogger

Logs a message to stdout using println. The priority is displayed with ANSI colors and the tag is prepended to the message if one is provided.

Logs a message to stdout using println. The priority is displayed with ANSI colors and the tag is prepended to the message if one is provided.

ownPages.title: ClogThrowableLogger
ownPages.content:
The entry-point for logging throwables to Clog.

v

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.VERBOSE level.

d

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.DEBUG level.

i

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.INFO level.

log

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.DEFAULT level.

w

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.WARNING level.

e

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.ERROR level.

wtf

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.FATAL level.

ownPages.title: ClogPlatform
ownPages.content:
Acutal/expect declarations for Clog

inferCurrentTag

Infer a tag for a log message, on supported platforms. Typically, this inspects stackframes to determine the calling class.

Returns null if the platform does not support a mechanism for inferring a tag, or if there is an error attempting to determine the tag.

createDefaultLogger

Create a new instance of the platform-specific ClogLogger . This may be conditional, returning different implementations based on conditions like OS and ANSI control code support.

createDefaultTagProvider

Create a new instance of the platform-specific ClogTagProvider .

createDefaultFilter

Create a new instance of the platform-specific ClogFilter .

createDefaultMessageFormatter

Create a new instance of the platform-specific ClogMessageFormatter .

ownPages.title: ClogProfile
ownPages.content:
The standard entry-point to logging messages to Clog. Messages will be filtered by the filter , and messages that pass the filter will be formatted with messageFormatter and logged to logger with a tag provided by tagProvider .

logger

tagProvider

filter

messageFormatter

The standard entry-point to logging messages to Clog. Messages will be filtered by the filter , and messages that pass the filter will be formatted with messageFormatter and logged to logger with a tag provided by tagProvider .

v

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.VERBOSE level with additional positional args.

v

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.VERBOSE level.

d

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.DEBUG level with additional positional args.

d

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.DEBUG level.

i

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.INFO level with additional positional args.

i

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.INFO level.

w

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.WARNING level with additional positional args.

w

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.WARNING level.

e

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.ERROR level with additional positional args.

e

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.ERROR level.

wtf

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.FATAL level with additional positional args.

wtf

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.FATAL level.

log

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.DEFAULT level with additional positional args.

log

Filters, formats, and logs a message. This is an internal method that should not be called directly. Use the methods from ClogProfile or clog.dsl instead.

log

Logs a Throwable at the Clog.Priority.DEFAULT level.

logException

Filters and logs a Throwable. This is an internal method that should not be called directly. Use the methods from ClogProfile or clog.dsl instead.

ownPages.title: ClogLogger
ownPages.content:
Log a message to a platform-specific logging target,

log

Log a message at a given priority to a platform-specific logging target. The tag is already inferred and the message already formatted at this point.

logException

ownPages.title: ClogMessageFormatter
ownPages.content:
Formats a log message with positional args and any other contextual information.

format

Formats a log message with positional args and any other contextual information. Tags and logging levels are handled by the ClogLogger and should not be included in this formatted message.

ownPages.title: ClogFilter
ownPages.content:
Determines whether a message should be logged. Only logs passing the filter will continue to be formatted with the ClogMessageFormatter and sent to the ClogLogger .

addTagToWhitelist

Declare a tag that should be added to the whitelist. Only messages with a tag in the whitelist will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

addTagToBlacklist

Declare a tag that should be added to the blacklist. Only messages with a tag not in the blacklist will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

setMinPriority

Set the minimum priority for log messages. Only messages with a level greater than or equal to priority will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

shouldLog

Given a priority and tag , determine if a message should be logged. It should conform to the whitelist, blacklist, and minimum priority, but additional logic may be present as well.

Returns true if the message should be logged, and false if it should be dropped.

ownPages.title: ClogTagProvider
ownPages.content:
Provides a tag to log with the message. This should be a globally-configured tag stored in the ClogProfile or a tag inferred by the platform, if available.

get

Return the tag that should be logged with the current message.

ownPages.title: clog.api
ownPages.content:
ClogFilter

Determines whether a message should be logged. Only logs passing the filter will continue to be formatted with the ClogMessageFormatter and sent to the ClogLogger .

ClogLogger

Log a message to a platform-specific logging target,

ClogMessageFormatter

Formats a log message with positional args and any other contextual information.

ClogTagProvider

Provides a tag to log with the message. This should be a globally-configured tag stored in the ClogProfile or a tag inferred by the platform, if available.

ownPages.title: clog.dsl
ownPages.content:
updateProfile

Update the current ClogProfile instance, returning the new profile to set as the global profile.

tag

Returns a copy of the global ClogProfile instance with a specified tag.

maybeTag

If tag is not null, return a copy of the global ClogProfile with that tag specified. Otherwise, directly return the global ClogProfile .

configureLoggingInProduction

Configures Clog to only log messages in debug builds. If isDebug is true, then logs will be filtered normally, delegating to the previously-configured filter. If isDebug is false, then all logs will be ignored and no messages will be logged.

addLogger

Adds an additional ClogLogger as a logging target.

addTagToWhitelist

Declare a tag that should be added to the whitelist. Only messages with a tag in the whitelist will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

addTagToBlacklist

Declare a tag that should be added to the blacklist. Only messages with a tag not in the blacklist will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

setMinPriority

Set the minimum priority for log messages. Only messages with a level greater than or equal to priority will be logged.

Returns a copy of this ClogFilter with this change to be set in the ClogProfile .

v

Log an unformatted message at the Clog.Priority.VERBOSE level. The global ClogMessageFormatter is provided to the lambda to allow the format() method to be called if message formatting is needed.

d

Log an unformatted message at the Clog.Priority.DEBUG level. The global ClogMessageFormatter is provided to the lambda to allow the format() method to be called if message formatting is needed.

i

Log an unformatted message at the Clog.Priority.INFO level. The global ClogMessageFormatter is provided to the lambda to allow the format() method to be called if message formatting is needed.

log

Log an unformatted message at the Clog.Priority.DEFAULT level. The global ClogMessageFormatter is provided to the lambda to allow the format() method to be called if message formatting is needed.

w

Log an unformatted message at the Clog.Priority.WARNING level. The global ClogMessageFormatter is provided to the lambda to allow the format() method to be called if message formatting is needed.

e

Log an unformatted message at the Clog.Priority.ERROR level. The global ClogMessageFormatter is provided to the lambda to allow the format() method to be called if message formatting is needed.

wtf

Log an unformatted message at the Clog.Priority.FATAL level. The global ClogMessageFormatter is provided to the lambda to allow the format() method to be called if message formatting is needed.

format

Formats a message with positional args and any other contextual information.

shouldLog

Given a priority and tag , determine if a message should be logged. It should conform to the whitelist, blacklist, and minimum priority, but additional logic may be present as well.

Returns true if the message should be logged, and false if it should be dropped.

ownPages.title: ClogMessageLogger
ownPages.content:
The entry-point for logging messages to Clog.

v

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.VERBOSE level with additional positional args.

d

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.DEBUG level with additional positional args.

i

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.INFO level with additional positional args.

log

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.DEFAULT level with additional positional args.

w

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.WARNING level with additional positional args.

e

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.ERROR level with additional positional args.

wtf

Logs a message at the Clog.Priority.FATAL level with additional positional args.

addTagToWhitelist

Declare a tag that should be added to the whitelist. Only messages with a tag in the whitelist will be logged.

clog.api

clog.dsl

clog.impl

clog.util

ownPages.title: Common
ownPages.content:
Clog

Zero-config Kotlin multiplatform logging utility, strongly inspired by the SLF4J and Timber APIs.

Clog is designed with the following goals in mind:

  • Zero setup required: just add the dependency and start logging
  • Support natural logging for each platform: use actual/expect declarations to provide natural logging targets for each platform, rather than printing everything to stdout
  • Be a central logger: Unlike many other Kotlin/Multiplatform loggers which simply delegate to SLF4j, Clog is designed to be the central logger instead of a wrapper around another logger. Clog is an SLF4J implementation, so logs from other libraries will be passed through to Clog and can be configured and filtered using Clog's APIs.
  • Support existing standards for logging: with the API of Timber and semantics compatible with SLF4J, Clog is a natural way to transition your JVM-specific logging into the Kotlin/Multiplatform world
  • Customization is there if you need it: the Clog singleton can be easily configured with custom classes to apply your own formatting, filtering, and logging targets
  • Immutable loggers: The ClogProfile and all classes implementing the logger are immutable, for multithreaded performance and safety. The global Clog instance is updated only by swapping out the backing instance, and you're free to bypass the global instance entirely and inject loggers instead.

Supported Platforms/Features

PlatformLogging TargetANSI ColorsTag InferenceMessage FormattingSLF4J IntegrationSLF4J MDC Support
JVMSystem.out
Androidandroid.util.Log
JSconsole.log
iOSNSLog

Installation

repositories {
    jcenter()
    maven(url = "https://dl.bintray.com/copper-leaf/oss")
}

// for plain JVM or Android projects
dependencies {
    implementation("io.copper-leaf:clog:3.6.0")
}

// for multiplatform projects
kotlin {
    sourceSets {
        val commonMain by getting {
            dependencies {
                implementation("clog:core:3.6.0")
            }
        }
    }
}

Usage

Clog's logging levels generally follow the SLF4J logging levels, and the API follows a similar API as android.util.log or Timber.

Clog LevelClog MethodSLF4J Level
VerboseClog.v()logger.trace()
DebugClog.d()logger.debug()
InfoClog.i()logger.info()
DefaultClog.log()N/A
WarningClog.w()logger.warn()
ErrorClog.e()logger.error()
FatalClog.wtf()N/A

In general, a log consists of a message (which may be formatted with params in SLF4J-style), a tag, and a log level. Below is a description of the API

Normal log messages

Tag will be inferred on supported platforms, based on the calling class

Clog.v("message")
Clog.d("message")
Clog.i("message")
Clog.log("message")
Clog.w("message")
Clog.e("message")
Clog.wtf("message")

Logs with custom tags

Clog.tag("tag").v("message")
Clog.tag("tag").d("message")
Clog.tag("tag").i("message")
Clog.tag("tag").w("message")
Clog.tag("tag").e("message")
Clog.tag("tag").wtf("message")

Log exceptions

val e = RuntimeException()
Clog.v(e)
Clog.d(e)
Clog.i(e)
Clog.log(e)
Clog.w(e)
Clog.e(e)
Clog.wtf(e)

Message Formatting

SLF4j-style formatting is supported, replacing {} with params passed to the logging call. This is supported on all platforms and all log levels.

val foo = "bar"
Clog.i("message {}", foo) // logs 'message bar'

Priority Filter

Messages and exceptions can be filtered out by priority.

Clog.setMinPriority(Clog.Priority.ERROR)

Tag whitelisting/blacklisting

Messages can be filtered out by tags.

Clog.addTagToWhitelist("tag1")
Clog.addTagToBlacklist("tag2")

Lambda DSL

Using the Clog DSL, simple strings can be logged lazily. The lambda is only evaluated if the logging level and tag is enabled. By default, messages logged with the lambda DSL are not formatted, but it can be re-enabled by using format() inside the lambda.

Normal log messages

import clog.dsl.*

v   { "message" }
d   { "message" }
i   { "message" }
w   { "message" }
e   { "message" }
wtf { "message" }

Logs with custom tags

import clog.dsl.*

v("tag")   { "message" }
d("tag")   { "message" }
i("tag")   { "message" }
w("tag")   { "message" }
e("tag")   { "message" }
wtf("tag") { "message" }

Message formatting

import clog.dsl.*

val foo = "bar" 
v   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
d   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
i   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
w   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
e   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
wtf { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'

SLF4J

On plain JVM and Android platforms, Clog is set up as an SLF4J binding; that is, SLF4J will pass log messages through to Clog. Other libraries and frameworks logging to SLF4J will be formatted as normal Clog logs for uniform log output, and so Clog can be used as a simple SLF4J binding when you don't want to configure Logback. Additionally, SLF Mapped Diagnostic Context (MDC) is supported, and context data can be added to log messages with the standard format of %X{mdcKey}.

val slf4j: Logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(JvmClogSlf4jTest::class.java)

MDC.put("akey", "avalue")
slf4j.trace("message %X{akey}") // logs 'message avalue' to the Clog logger

More Customization

Clog is designed to work out-of-the-box with absolutely zero config required to start logging with it. However, you can customize all components of Clog to your needs. Clog is comprised of several components wrapped in a ClogProfile, which is the global instance of Clog.getInstance(). You can customize your Clog by creating a new Profile with your custom components:

val newProfile = ClogProfile(...)
Clog.setProfile(newProfile)

You can also use the Clog.updateProfile helper to create a profile based on the current global instance:

Clog.updateProfile { it.copy(logger = newLogger) }

The table below describes the classes that can be customized in the ClogProfile, along with their default implementation for each supported platform:

InterfaceDescriptionJVMAndroidJSiOS
ClogTagProviderInfers a tag if one is not provided to the logging callDefaultTagProvider()DefaultTagProvider()DefaultTagProvider()DefaultTagProvider()
ClogMessageFormatterFormats a message string to pass to the ClogLoggerSlf4jMessageFormatter(DefaultMessageFormatter())DefaultMessageFormatter()DefaultMessageFormatter()DefaultMessageFormatter()
ClogFilterDetermines whether to format and log a messageDefaultFilter()DefaultFilter()DefaultFilter()DefaultFilter()
ClogLoggerPrints a formatted log to a lower-level platform-specific logger or consoleDefaultLogger()AndroidLogger()JsConsoleLogger()NsLogger()

Recipes

Turn off logging in production

val isDebug = ...
Clog.configureLoggingInProduction(isDebug)

Use a custom logger

Replaces the current logging target with a custom one.

val customLogger = object : ClogLogger {
    override fun log(priority: Clog.Priority, tag: String?, message: String) {
        ...
    }
    override fun logException(priority: Clog.Priority, tag: String?, throwable: Throwable) {
        ...
    }
}
Clog.updateProfile { it.copy(logger = customLogger) }

Using multiple logging targets

Add an additional logger to the current instance. Calling addLogger multiple times will continue adding loggers, and messages will be delegated to all loggers.

val customLogger = object : ClogLogger {
    override fun log(priority: Clog.Priority, tag: String?, message: String) {
        ...
    }
    override fun logException(priority: Clog.Priority, tag: String?, throwable: Throwable) {
        ...
    }
}
Clog.addLogger(customLogger)

Using Clog with dependency injection

// Given some classes that depend on a logger
class Controller(val logger: ClogProfile) 

// just declare a ClogProfile singleton with any configurations you need 
val module = module { 
  single { ClogProfile() } 
  single { Controller(get()) } 
}

Clog is an SLF4J implementation, so logs from other libraries will be passed through to Clog and can be configured and filtered using Clog's APIs.
  • Support existing standards for logging: with the API of Timber and semantics compatible with SLF4J, Clog is a natural way to transition your JVM-specific logging into the Kotlin/Multiplatform world
  • Customization is there if you need it: the Clog singleton can be easily configured with custom classes to apply your own formatting, filtering, and logging targets

Messages can be filtered out by tags.

Clog.addTagToWhitelist("tag1")
Clog.addTagToBlacklist("tag2")

Lambda DSL

Using the Clog DSL, simple strings can be logged lazily. The lambda is only evaluated if the logging level and tag is enabled. By default, messages logged with the lambda DSL are not formatted, but it can be re-enabled by using format() inside the lambda.

Normal log messages

import clog.dsl.*

v   { "message" }
d   { "message" }
i   { "message" }
w   { "message" }
e   { "message" }
wtf { "message" }

Logs with custom tags

import clog.dsl.*

v("tag")   { "message" }
d("tag")   { "message" }
i("tag")   { "message" }
w("tag")   { "message" }
e("tag")   { "message" }
wtf("tag") { "message" }

Message formatting

import clog.dsl.*

val foo = "bar" 
v   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
d   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
i   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
w   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
e   { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'
wtf { format("message {}", foo) } // logs 'message bar'

SLF4J

On plain JVM and Android platforms, Clog is set up as an SLF4J binding; that is, SLF4J will pass log messages through to Clog. Other libraries and frameworks logging to SLF4J will be formatted as normal Clog logs for uniform log output, and so Clog can be used as a simple SLF4J binding when you don't want to configure Logback. Additionally, SLF Mapped Diagnostic Context (MDC) is supported, and context data can be added to log messages with the standard format of %X{mdcKey}.

val slf4j: Logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(JvmClogSlf4jTest::class.java)

MDC.put("akey", "avalue")
slf4j.trace("message %X{akey}") // logs 'message avalue' to the Clog logger

More Customization

Clog is designed to work out-of-the-box with absolutely zero config required to start logging with it. However, you can customize all components of Clog to your needs. Clog is comprised of several components wrapped in a ClogProfile, which is the global instance of Clog.getInstance(). You can customize your Clog by creating a new Profile with your custom components:

val newProfile = ClogProfile(...)
Clog.setProfile(newProfile)

You can also use the Clog.updateProfile helper to create a profile based on the current global instance:

Clog.updateProfile { it.copy(logger = newLogger) }

The table below describes the classes that can be customized in the ClogProfile, along with their default implementation for each supported platform:

InterfaceDescriptionJVMAndroidJSiOS
ClogTagProviderInfers a tag if one is not provided to the logging callDefaultTagProvider()DefaultTagProvider()DefaultTagProvider()DefaultTagProvider()
ClogMessageFormatterFormats a message string to pass to the ClogLoggerSlf4jMessageFormatter(DefaultMessageFormatter())DefaultMessageFormatter()DefaultMessageFormatter()DefaultMessageFormatter()
ClogFilterDetermines whether to format and log a messageDefaultFilter()DefaultFilter()DefaultFilter()DefaultFilter()
ClogLoggerPrints a formatted log to a lower-level platform-specific logger or consoleDefaultLogger()AndroidLogger()JsConsoleLogger()NsLogger()

Recipes

Turn off logging in production

val isDebug = ...
Clog.configureLoggingInProduction(isDebug)

Use a custom logger

Replaces the current logging target with a custom one.

val customLogger = object : ClogLogger {
    override fun log(priority: Clog.Priority, tag: String?, message: String) {
        ...
    }
    override fun logException(priority: Clog.Priority, tag: String?, throwable: Throwable) {
        ...
    }
}
Clog.updateProfile { it.copy(logger = customLogger) }

Using multiple logging targets

Add an additional logger to the current instance. Calling addLogger multiple times will continue adding loggers, and messages will be delegated to all loggers.

val customLogger = object : ClogLogger {
    override fun log(priority: Clog.Priority, tag: String?, message: String) {
        ...
    }
    override fun logException(priority: Clog.Priority, tag: String?, throwable: Throwable) {
        ...
    }
}
Clog.addLogger(customLogger)

Using Clog with dependency injection

// Given some classes that depend on a logger
class Controller(val logger: ClogProfile) 

// just declare a ClogProfile singleton with any configurations you need 
val module = module { 
  single { ClogProfile() } 
  single { Controller(get()) } 
}
